response.answer_text: Simple: You make it so the interests of the media align with those of conservatives. The linguist and left-wing activist Noam Chomsky proposed his model of how the American media operates in his 1988 book Manufacturing Consent, coauthored with economist Edward S. Herman. This model is called the propaganda model, and proves to be amazingly effective.  The book lays out five “filters” through which any media reporting must pass before it makes it to the general public. 1. Ownership — The reporting of a media corporation will be skewed towards the material interests of its owners. Example: Many of the people who own American media enterprises also have significant stocks in American arms manufacturing, leading to a hawkish stance on military intervention. 2. Advertising — It will be skewed towards the material interests of corporations that use the publication to advertise. Example: Multinational corporations will air commercials for their products on news networks if they feel these news networks might criticise them. If the media does criticise, they stop advertising there, which means the network loses money. 3. Sources — It will be skewed towards the material interests of the sources that provide information to the journalists. Example: American news networks tend to be very forgiving towards law enforcement, since the police provides them with a lot of sensational stories. Often they will accept cute stories about policemen saving dogs over instances of police abuse, simply because these stories are readily provided to them. Another example: If a lot of people post about something on social media, media corporations are likely to pick up this story due to the amount of readily available information. 4. Flak — When a problematic story does come through, corporations may be faced by large and organised resistance against it. Other media companies might frame their reporting in a bad light. Influential think tanks may start publishing materials slandering the company. Readers may start sending angry letters. Example: Stories critical of Israel are often attacked for being anti-Semitic by pro-Israel organisations. 5. Fear — Fear of an external enemy is a powerful filter over what a media company is able to publish. They cannot be seen publishing stories that make excuses for a perceived enemy. Examples: Attacks on socialism during the Cold War. Attacks on Islam after 9/11. Attacks on Russia nowadays.  If you play into these five factors effectively, you can easily manipulate the media into being more conservative. Conservatives already have a significant advantage in most of them. Media companies are owned by corporations, they are advertised in by corporations, their sources tend to be law enforcement and the military, and fear is characteristic of conservative psychology.
